content: original harvie leftovers child s jumper by kate harvie about the pattern the adults have had an original harvie leftovers jumper for several years now and are still queueing up for them the babies got their jacket pattern in january 2024 and now the older children are asking for one yes honestly so this is the version for children aged 2-12 as with the adult size jumper it s a simple drop shoulder knitted from the bottom up using two strands of dk yarn held together without body shaping and with classic tapered sleeves picked up around the armholes and knitted downwards of course children vary a lot in size so the ages given here are only a suggestion this jumper should be worn fairly loosely if in doubt go up a size pick a size based on the page1 of 9 copyright © kate harvie all rights reserved for personal use only 13 august 2024 chest measurement and you can adjust the length by working a longer or shorter body up to the armholes note that the measurements given here are finished garment sizes you should pick a size 10-15cm 4-6 inches above the actual body measurement the pictures show m wearing size 3 and c wearing size 5 skill level beginner techniques include casting on binding off knit purl simple increases and decreases picking up stitches and three needle bind-off sizing the pattern is described in eight sizes to fit children from ages 2-12 in the pattern instructions these are described as 1st 2nd etc to 8th size the instructions for the first size are given first with sizes 2-5 in square brackets and sizes 6-8 in curly brackets thus eg k 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 if there is no instruction necessary for a particular size this will be shown with a dash thus eg k 5 4 3 2 1 - - - instructions to be repeated are enclosed in round brackets thus eg k2 p2 twice stitch counts are given in italics finished measurements after blocking finished chest circumference 63 65 5 68 5 71 5 74 5 77 80 85 5 cm 24 75 25 75 27 28 25 29 25 30 25 31 5 33 75 in yarn it is difficult to be definite about the quantity of yarn needed for this jumper essentially you need a bag of dk yarn it should all be relatively similar in type but as the idea is to use up leftovers then it does not need to be identical this is part of the charm don t use chenille yarn as it has no stretch at all and will look terrible apart from this it s up to you if you have a lot of 4ply fingering or sock yarn to use up you can substitute 1 strand of dk with 2 strands of 4ply you will need to allow more yarn than the bare minimum to get a nice balance of colours
